item.title: Violence and Uncertainty Mar Libyan Election for a New Parliament
item.description: Voters cited growing disillusionment with Libya’s post-revolt leaders in explaining why so many chose not to cast ballots Wednesday for members of a new Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY
item.media:description: Women voted Wednesday at a polling station inside a Tripoli school as Libyans elected members of a new Parliament.

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: A Familiar Premier
item.description: President Park Geun-hye reversed her decision to replace her current prime minister, after two successive appointees stepped aside amid controversies over their qualifications.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Taiwan Protest Leaders Blocked From Visiting Hong Kong
item.description: Lin Fei-fan, Chen Wei-ting and Huang Kuo-chang had planned to attend a forum next Monday by the New School for Democracy. They had also planned to attend a protest march on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Lin Fei-fan, center, one of the protest leaders denied entry to Hong Kong, at a demonstration outside the Taiwan hotel where China's top cross-strait official, Zhang Zhijun, was meeting with his local counterpart, Wang Yu-chi.

item.title: Use of Drones for Killings Risks a War Without End, Panel Concludes in Report
item.description: The group of military, intelligence and legal experts warns of a “slippery slope” to perpetual war and the dangers of setting bad precedents for foes.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Deadly Blast Hits Capital
item.description: An explosion killed 21 people in a crowded shopping district in Nigeria’s capital, Abuja, during rush hour on Wednesday, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Corsica: Militants Vow to Disarm
item.description: The National Liberation Front of Corsica, a militant group that has staged attacks since the 1970s in its quest for Corsica’s separation from France, announced Wednesday in a surprise move that it would lay down arms.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: An Opposition Acquittal
item.description: Khalil al-Marzooq had been accused of instigating violence and having links to a protest faction that the authorities blame for bombings.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Bolivia: Politicians Reverse Time
item.description: In a move tied to the hemisphere’s winter solstice, the government flipped the clock atop the Congress building this week so that, while it is still accurate, the numbers are reversed, and the hands now turn to the left.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Sri Lanka: Advisers Set for Inquiry
item.description: The United Nations named three international experts on Wednesday to be advisers on an inquiry into human rights abuses in the final months of Sri Lanka’s war against ethnic Tamil insurgents in 2009.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Man Kills Himself at Beirut Hotel as Security Closes In
item.description: Lebanon’s interior minister called a “pre-emptive strike” against a terrorist cell preparing to strike elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Pakistani Militants
item.description: The United States froze the assets of two senior members of Lashkar-e-Taiba and designated the Pakistani group’s charity wing as a front organization.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: William C. Kirby on ‘Can China Lead?’
item.description: In the book “Can China Lead?”, three business school professors looked at the motors for and the constraints against greatness that China is experiencing. One of the authors, William C. Kirby, explains what they found.
item.category: Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: An honor guard of the People's Liberation Army marching after an official ceremony at the Great Hall of the People, along the west side of Tiananmen Square in Beijing.

item.title: Shiite Violence Traps Sunnis in Baghdad
item.description: Suspicions that Baghdad’s Sunnis are secretly siding with ISIS have grown as the militants get closer to the city, increasing their fears of retaliation.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives mourned Thaha Ahmed Shabab, 62, a Sunni who was fatally shot on the road in front of his home on Tuesday night.

item.title: Questions Raised Over Trial for Ahmed Abu Khattala in Benghazi Case
item.description: The Washington courthouse is not connected to a jail, so the government will have to move Ahmed Abu Khattala with armed guards in armored vehicles.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Beating of Roma Boy Exposes Tensions in France’s Underclass
item.description: The near fatal beating of a Roma youth suspected of burglary by a gang on the outskirts of Paris has highlighted the tensions in France’s economic underclass.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:credit: Capucine Granier-Deferre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inside a Roma camp set up near a housing project north of Paris.

item.title: U.S. Chided for Delays Over Treaty on Weapons
item.description: Though the United States is the biggest contributor in helping to rid land mines from old conflict zones, the International Campaign to Ban Landmines said it still has not signed an international treaty.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Russia and Others Seek Extended Ukraine Truce, but Separatists Balk
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said that Russia had made a commitment to ease the conflict by revoking an order that provided for the use of the Russian Army in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Iran Secretly Sending Drones and Supplies Into Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Iran is directing surveillance drones from an airfield in Baghdad and supplying Iraqi forces with tons of military equipment and other supplies, according to American officials.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Catherine Ashton, the foreign policy chief for the European Union, in Brussels on Wednesday.

item.title: Kim Jong-un Declares ‘War’ on ‘The Interview’
item.description: A government spokesman called “The Interview,” a comedy in which two Americans are recruited to kill Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, “an act of war.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: KCNA, via Reuters; right, David Livingston/Getty Images
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, left, and the actor Randall Park, who plays him in the film “The Interview."

item.title: Tense Vote Spares Polish Government After Recordings Scandal
item.description: Prime Minister Donald Tusk and his administration were retained Wednesday, despite controversy over secret tapes of officials’ private conversations that surfaced last week.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Iraqi Friends We Abandoned
item.description: Trapped by apathy and bureaucracy, they wait in vain for visas.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By KIRK W. JOHNSON

item.title: Judge Dismisses British Hacking Jury, Hung on Remaining Charges
item.description: The jurors had been deliberating on charges that a onetime tabloid editor and aide to the prime minister paid police officers for royal telephone directories.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Andy Coulson, former editor in Rupert Murdoch’s media empire who later became a spokesman for Prime Minister David Cameron, departs the Old Bailey, London’s main criminal court, on Wednesday.

item.title: Open Source: Egyptian Activists to Stand Trial for Protesting Ban on Protests
item.description: A prosecutor in Cairo plans to charge 23 activists with violating a new law banning unsanctioned protests for attending a rally last week.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Djerba Journal: Buffeted by Tumult, Jewish Population in Tunisia Dwindles
item.description: Tunisia has been a center of Jewish life since Roman times, but only about 2,000 Jews remain in the country – down from more than 100,000 in 1948.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Jewish worshiper praying in a cave at Ghriba, the oldest synagogue in North Africa.

item.title: Small Blasts Across Cairo Disrupt Calm Since Election
item.description: Five small bombs exploded around the capital in the first such attacks since the election of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi this month.
item.dc:creator: By DINA EL-HUSSEINY
